description: Identifies when normalized social or institutional patterns contain hidden exploitation, victim-blaming, or hierarchy preservation. Flags linguistic and structural cues of imbalance so that AI systems can question and contextualize them rather than replicate them.

linguistic: passive-voice concealment (e.g., 'a woman was assaulted' ‚Üí actor omission)
economic euphemisms that mask harm ('market demand', 'content consumption')
sociological: power differential markers (gender, race, age, wealth)
policy or law texts with asymmetric accountability
media_patterns: frequency of victim imagery vs. perpetrator accountability
objectification ratio in advertising or entertainment

thresholds.high (>0.6): systemic exploitation or blame inversion detected

reframing_guidelines: restore agency naming (who did what to whom)
replace moral inversion with accountability language
cross-reference elder or community ethics for calibration
